captions.text:
Well, this is what they call &quot;making a rod
for your own back,&quot; I suppose.

See, Smash Brothers on the Wii U came out
and the usual suspects all scurried up my

garden path waving it but I slammed the door
and went &quot;Sorry, much as I&#39;d love to join

you in Nintendo&#39;s paddling pool full of self-satisfied
cum, there&#39;s no single player content, so

damn, hands tied, if only I liked multiplayer
games and wasn&#39;t quite so good at alienating
people.&quot;

So now of course Smash Bros Ultimate comes
out with a story mode and I can&#39;t use that
excuse anymore.
Back up the garden path they come.

&quot;Oh please review Smash Ultimate Yahtzee please
please please there&#39;s a story mode.&quot;
Look, it&#39;s not really my &quot;thing&quot;, alright?

&quot;Oh please review it anyway everyone else
is talking about it we&#39;d love to hear your
take.&quot;
Fine, here&#39;s my take.

&quot;Eurgh, we didn&#39;t like your take, you shouldn&#39;t
have reviewed it if it wasn&#39;t your thing&quot;
FOR FUCK&#39;S SAKE.

I want to know what you whinging cunts were
expecting.
Did you think I would finally be converted?

Oh yes, this specific combination of characters
and slight gameplay tweaks has finally made

me see Smash Bros for more than just a colourful
button mashing stroke nostalgic wank exercise.
I am now a Nintendo fan.

Please let me know where to report for my
free amiibo and lobotomy.
No, that&#39;s not how it works, is it.

Smash Brothers doesn&#39;t create Nintendo fans,
it leeches off them.

You become a fan of a character from their
own game, not from seeing them in Smash Bros.

Mainly &#39;cos you can&#39;t fucking see them in
Smash Brothers from all the particle effects

and the camera being pulled back far from
the action like me at all my high school discos.

So I ask myself how I would feel about a fighting
game populated with all my favourite characters.

A game in which Modesty Blaise and Major Kira
can team up to bring down Horatio Hornblower
and the Arkhamverse Riddler.

And yes, I suppose I would get a kick out
of that, but I wouldn&#39;t expect anyone else
to who didn&#39;t know the characters.

It would only be the superficial appearance
of Modesty Blaise with none of the nuances

from the comic strip that make her a great
character - the personality, the backstory,
the surprising amount of gratuitous nudity.

Actually Smash Bros has a close equivalent
to that with Bayonetta, and sure enough, little

of that character&#39;s actual personality is
conveyed.

She&#39;s even depicted with realistic human proportions,
which kinda threw me.

Without legs like an unfolded stepladder she
just looks like that one friend of your mum

who kept wanting to hang out with you when
you were a kid because she was still single

at thirty-four and the ticking of her biological
clock had become as loud as a malfunctioning
lawnmower engine.
But anyway.

Smash Bros Ultimate does indeed have a story
mode, but it&#39;s not much of one and you need

to turn over a few rocks in the main menu
to find it.

If you&#39;re expecting the sumptuous buffet of
laughably earnest cinematics and specially

designed platforming levels that was the Smash
Bros Brawl story mode then you can go stick

your head between your legs and wait for your
rectum to dispense butterscotch angel delight.

All you get this time around is two cinematics
- one at the front, one at the end - and approximately

five hundred billion squillion random battles
against the AI.

The story is, all the fighters have been captured
by two godlike forces, a white circle representing
light and a black circle representing dark.
Sterling creativity on display there.

What was the inspiration, Nintendo, the stains
on your favourite nightdress?

The only fighter who isn&#39;t consumed is Kirby,
possibly because the evil gods were both diabetic,

and so it&#39;s up to them to explore an open-ended
map screen battling and unlocking characters
as he, she or it goes.
It&#39;s a deceptively long campaign.

Every time I thought I was close to completing
the map they&#39;d pull out another fucking map,

it was like being the only filing clerk at
the cartography department.

Because you don&#39;t just unlock fighters, there
are also hundreds upon hundreds of what are

termed &#39;spirits&#39;, basically still images of
video game characters who didn&#39;t quite have
the clout for a full on appearance.

You fight whichever fighter or fighters most
closely approximates the spirit, like for

example, Otacon from Metal Gear Solid is represented
by Dr Mario and a Rob robot, gotcha, although

personally I&#39;d have gone with a Squirtle in
glasses or something equally moist.

Unlocked spirits convey various buffs and
you swap them out before each battle to best
counter your opponent.

And the whole &quot;Nintendo characters crossover&quot;
remit which was already getting shaky with

all the guest characters is now officially
in the bin because the spirits are from all
over the place.

You&#39;ve got Shantae, Rayman, the chicks from
Fatal Frame, blimey Nintendo&#39;s in bed with

a lot of people, it&#39;s gonna end up with a
snatch like an inside-out pink ski sock.

I wish there was an in-game database explaining
where some of these spirits were from.

Perhaps the game would have had some value
then as a virtual museum, but no, all you

get is an image, so all you&#39;re basically doing
is filling out a sticker album.
At its core it&#39;s about the combat.
And yeah, it&#39;s Smash Brothers.

You mash buttons and hope all those particle
effects are coming out of them and not you.

Every now and again your tiny opponent gestures
vaguely with a limb that&#39;s like two pixels

big on screen and you promptly get blasted
into the cosmos and you&#39;re left wondering

what the fuck that was and how you were supposed
to predict it.

So for a while I was struggling along not
having much fun, but everything abruptly changed

after I unlocked Donkey Kong, who I proceeded
to exclusively play as.
Why?

Because (A) he&#39;s big and cartoony enough that
you can actually read his fucking movements,

and (B) he has this one attack that I like
to call &quot;fuck off I win ook ook&quot; where he

slaps the ground and everyone in a ten yard
radius explodes.

I ended up challenging myself not to use it
because I jerk off sailors for nickels and
even I thought it was cheap.

Things went pretty smooth after that until
the final boss when I had to pick two additional

characters to use besides Donkey Kong, which
was like pulling me out of my nice comfortable

roadster and forcing me to do the final lap
on a unicycle.

But you know what, I didn&#39;t dislike playing
to story end.

It was samey and prolonged but there were
moments when I&#39;d land a fully wound up donkey
punch that made my trousers tighten with satisfaction.

So what is it about Smash Brothers that irritates
me?
I think I&#39;ve finally figured it out.

See, I believe in video games as an ever-progressing
art form, and while I&#39;m sure Smash is a lot

of fun when you gather your mates around it,
the same is true of poking a dead fox with

a stick, and I don&#39;t think Smash has any artistic
value.

It&#39;s got so many characters, but it doesn&#39;t
add anything to them, it just references them
superficially.
It&#39;s &quot;Hey, who remembers this?
The Game.&quot;

Breath of the Wild is a great game with a
lot of artistic value but Link&#39;s appearance

in Smash Ultimate is to Breath of the Wild
what a TV commercial for action figures is
to the Empire Strikes Back.
And even that&#39;s not why it annoys me.

The artless does have a right to exist, hence
daytime television and KFC.

What annoys me is what an enormous fucking
profile the game has.

I resent the rest of gaming media for fixating
on it and letting it selfishly hog attention

away from games with actual new ideas and
stories to tell.

I despise the twatsanders who come up my garden
path demanding I review it and messing up

the plastic flamingos for wanting me to join
them in an unproductive circle jerk.

So just to clarify, I don&#39;t hate you, Smash
Brothers.
I don&#39;t even hate your fans.
I just wish they&#39;d shut up.
And wipe the spunk off my flamingos.
